Subjective: Left ear pain and sensation of water for 2-3 days; gradually worsening. Associated decreased hearing in left ear. Pain is manageable, rated 3-4/10, but increases to 6-7/10 after showering. Aggravated by swimming. Unable to swim due to pain. No fever, not feeling generally unwell. No painkillers taken. Social: New swimmer (few weeks). Cleans ears with cotton buds 3x/week. Request: Wants to know cause, wants pain relief and improved hearing. A little scared about the ear.
Objective: Vitals: Temp 36.2 C. Right Ear: External canal clear, tympanic membrane normal. Left Ear: Pain on pinna traction. External auditory canal is red, swollen, and thick. Tympanic membrane not well visualized.
Assessment: Left Otitis Externa, likely secondary to moisture from swimming and trauma from cotton bud use.
Plan: 1. Paracetamol up to 4000mg daily as needed for pain.
2. Prescribed acidic, anti-inflammatory ear drops for left ear, use three times a day for one week.
3. Advice: Keep left ear dry for one week (no swimming). Stop using cotton buds.
4. Follow-up: Return for re-evaluation in one week.
